The focus is on how the responses to the lack of alt-text is phrased tends to ignore the conditions that demand those responses in the first place. That is, we should be less concerned with the anger that disabled folks express, and more concerned about the conditions that make this anger necessary.

I could give any number of phenomenological, cultural, and social explanations for why people do not use alt-text be it through affordance theory, through the cultural politics of social media, through habit, but I shouldn't have to: just use the fucking alt-text. Make your shit accessible.

Nice to have the data to back up what I was experiencing. A lot of folks are just not using alt text. We should be encouraging folks to use alt text to make their images more accessible. Also reminding folks that they can flip the alt text reminder on in their settings if that is helpful.

Some new Bluesky stats for y'all.

We've seen ~400,000 posts per day for the past 9 days

Alt text usage has been holding steady at around ~26%
Around 15% of posts include images.

Daily active Posters floats around 70k
Daily active Likers floating around 90k

images.alt:
A graph of Daily Posts showing a recent plateau of around 400k posts per day. Before the plateau you can see a dip to around 300k posts per day and a surge at the start of the 30 day range of around 450k posts per day.

The graph also shows a line for % of posts with images and % of images with alt text. Alt text percentage fluctuates between 24% and 30% most recently plateauing around 26%.
A graph of active posters per day which fluctuates from ~80k to ~40k before surging up to >60k for the past 9 or so days.
A graph of likers per day showing ~85-90k average over the past 9 days, there is no data before then because I didn't start tracking the stat until recently.

In their view accessibility is imposed on the "normal" way of things, interrupting the smooth operation of the status quo. After all, why should they have to change what they're doing for a "small minority" of users who need alt-text? Why should they listen to people who're just imposing their will?

I could give any number of phenomenological, cultural, and social explanations for why people do not use alt-text be it through affordance theory, through the cultural politics of social media, through habit, but I shouldn't have to: just use the fucking alt-text. Make your shit accessible.

Nice to have the data to back up what I was experiencing. A lot of folks are just not using alt text. We should be encouraging folks to use alt text to make their images more accessible. Also reminding folks that they can flip the alt text reminder on in their settings if that is helpful.

It’s a quote that demands empathy and compassion, not nihilism and despair.

This is another Baldwin quote I love because of how it goes misinterpreted. Most people take this to mean that shitty things happen all the time under colonialism, that our suffering is not unique because everyone suffers. This is a nihilistic view.
“You think your pain and your heartbreak are unprecedented in the history of the world, but then you read.”

The better way to interpret this is that everyone has the capacity to suffer, that everyone can suffer, and because of this we need to be compassionate with one another, we need to try to reduce suffering in the world.

"My experience with liberals, they have attitudes, and they have all the proper attitudes. But they have no real convictions, and when the chips are down and you expect them to deliver and what you thought they felt they somehow are not there.” - James Baldwin
Thread of my favorite Baldwin quotes. Number 1 is obvious:

images.alt: To be a Negro in this country and to be relatively conscious is to be in a state of rage almost, almost all of the time — and in one's work. And part of the rage is this: It isn't only what is happening to you. But it's what's happening all around you and all of the time in the face of the most extraordinary and criminal indifference, indifference of most white people in this country, and their ignorance. Now, since this is so, it's a great temptation to simplify the issues under the illusion that if you simplify them enough, people will recognize them. I think this illusion is very dangerous because, in fact, it isn't the way it works. A complex thing can't be made simple. You simply have to try to deal with it in all its complexity and hope to get that complexity across.

app.bsky.feed.post.text:
Which is to say that every person, every activist, every revolutionary Black or otherwise, that attempts to reduce the experiences of Black suffering solely to racism is committing a great error.

This is the insight of this oft quoted passage from Baldwin.

This is my favorite Baldwin quote because it expresses so clearly not simply that Black people should be angry, which is where most people (even Black people) stop, but that the conditions of our world are what give rise to our anger, and among those conditions is white indifference and ignorance.

app.bsky.feed.post.text:
“There can be nothing more dangerous to a body than the social agreement that that body is dangerous.” 

- Sara Ahmed

Historically, any level of discomfort or “danger” has been used as an excuse to subject a Black person to varying levels of punishment for “not knowing their place” or for being a “threat”.

This has not been adequately unlearned and is still generally practiced by white folks in today’s society.

And this isn’t to say that Black folks can’t/don’t do kink or something, but to say that we have an entirely different set of concerns and ways we have to interact with the kink lifestyle because of ✨racism✨

I think I’ve gone over my main points I wanted to address on this topic!

Let’s talk Kink While Black.

I joined my local kink community at 18. Trained under two different Doms/Dommes in my home state, started teaching basic sensory play, especially knife play (not edgeplay) and other sensory tools after about 3 years. Taught professionally for groups after 4 years.

This isn’t based on a particular discourse rn, but like. I know the things I’ve done while being *extremely careful* that have been used against me due to antiblackness bc a white person felt like it, I can’t imagine doing some of the unhinged White People Shit y’all do because I’d be obliterated.

Because the risk isn’t just in the action of performing the kink, for Black folks, it’s also in what social repercussions we might be opening ourselves up to surrounding the kink. What racial stereotypes exist that may affect how we do the kink, or may stop us entirely.

Because the risk isn’t just in the action of performing the kink, for Black folks, it’s also in what social repercussions we might be opening ourselves up to surrounding the kink. What racial stereotypes exist that may affect how we do the kink, or may stop us entirely.

I joined my local kink community at 18. Trained under two different Doms/Dommes in my home state, started teaching basic sensory play, especially knife play (not edgeplay) and other sensory tools after about 3 years. Taught professionally for groups after 4 years.

This isn’t based on a particular discourse rn, but like. I know the things I’ve done while being *extremely careful* that have been used against me due to antiblackness bc a white person felt like it, I can’t imagine doing some of the unhinged White People Shit y’all do because I’d be obliterated.

Because of the potential for situations like these, because of the potential for racialization that Black folks experience, we have to have a COMPLETELY different risk calculus for what kinks are “safe” for us to participate in than white folks do. Because even if we do it right, we could be targets

Been recently playing with ideas for a story about a haunted house and struck repeatedly by how limiting contemporary western ideas of what “haunted” means can be
Explaining “kami” to students, for example, is real tough when they’re used to a western idea of what a spirit is or does, much less explaining that places have their own presences, their own kami.
Or simply having a nature and intentions which can’t be understood or predicted
And don’t EVEN get me started on “soul” and “mind” and “heart.”
One of the hardest things to explain when I teach non-western metaphysics is how western terms like spirit and ghost do fuck all to convey the meaning of non-western perspectives on the dead.

I agree. Sometimes I go along with calling my novel a ghost story but I really think of the no-longer-living person who narrates it as more of a spirit not what is connoted by the Western convention of a "ghost" with the spooky shock value. Nonwestern people live with our dead in different ways.
i don't think colonial representations of ghosts have much substance

Some new Bluesky stats for y'all.

We've seen ~400,000 posts per day for the past 9 days

Alt text usage has been holding steady at around ~26%
Around 15% of posts include images.

Daily active Posters floats around 70k
Daily active Likers floating around 90k

images.alt:
A graph of Daily Posts showing a recent plateau of around 400k posts per day. Before the plateau you can see a dip to around 300k posts per day and a surge at the start of the 30 day range of around 450k posts per day.

The graph also shows a line for % of posts with images and % of images with alt text. Alt text percentage fluctuates between 24% and 30% most recently plateauing around 26%.
A graph of active posters per day which fluctuates from ~80k to ~40k before surging up to >60k for the past 9 or so days.
A graph of likers per day showing ~85-90k average over the past 9 days, there is no data before then because I didn't start tracking the stat until recently.

record.text: The reactions you're describing are due to existing in a society that treats the act of asking for alt-text like an imposition. Disabled people who rely on these accommodations have had to bear the displeasure of an ableist world that would rather deny them full participation than accommodate them.

I could give any number of phenomenological, cultural, and social explanations for why people do not use alt-text be it through affordance theory, through the cultural politics of social media, through habit, but I shouldn't have to: just use the fucking alt-text. Make your shit accessible.

value.text: Nice to have the data to back up what I was experiencing. A lot of folks are just not using alt text. We should be encouraging folks to use alt text to make their images more accessible. Also reminding folks that they can flip the alt text reminder on in their settings if that is helpful.

A graph of active posters per day which fluctuates from ~80k to ~40k before surging up to >60k for the past 9 or so days.
A graph of likers per day showing ~85-90k average over the past 9 days, there is no data before then because I didn't start tracking the stat until recently.

This is another Baldwin quote I love because of how it goes misinterpreted. Most people take this to mean that shitty things happen all the time under colonialism, that our suffering is not unique because everyone suffers. This is a nihilistic view.

value.text: “You think your pain and your heartbreak are unprecedented in the history of the world, but then you read.”

record.text: The better way to interpret this is that everyone has the capacity to suffer, that everyone can suffer, and because of this we need to be compassionate with one another, we need to try to reduce suffering in the world.

This is my favorite Baldwin quote because it expresses so clearly not simply that Black people should be angry, which is where most people (even Black people) stop, but that the conditions of our world are what give rise to our anger, and among those conditions is white indifference and ignorance.

value.text: Thread of my favorite Baldwin quotes. Number 1 is obvious:

images.alt: To be a Negro in this country and to be relatively conscious is to be in a state of rage almost, almost all of the time — and in one's work. And part of the rage is this: It isn't only what is happening to you. But it's what's happening all around you and all of the time in the face of the most extraordinary and criminal indifference, indifference of most white people in this country, and their ignorance. Now, since this is so, it's a great temptation to simplify the issues under the illusion that if you simplify them enough, people will recognize them. I think this illusion is very dangerous because, in fact, it isn't the way it works. A complex thing can't be made simple. You simply have to try to deal with it in all its complexity and hope to get that complexity across.

To be a Negro in this country and to be relatively conscious is to be in a state of rage almost, almost all of the time — and in one's work. And part of the rage is this: It isn't only what is happening to you. But it's what's happening all around you and all of the time in the face of the most extraordinary and criminal indifference, indifference of most white people in this country, and their ignorance. Now, since this is so, it's a great temptation to simplify the issues under the illusion that if you simplify them enough, people will recognize them. I think this illusion is very dangerous because, in fact, it isn't the way it works. A complex thing can't be made simple. You simply have to try to deal with it in all its complexity and hope to get that complexity across.

record.text: Now, this is just the first part. The second part is what is important: the complexities of our experiences cannot be reduced or simplified and must be addressed in their complexity. This means that we need to bear in mind how racism intersects with other axis of oppression.

record.text:
Let’s talk Kink While Black.

I joined my local kink community at 18. Trained under two different Doms/Dommes in my home state, started teaching basic sensory play, especially knife play (not edgeplay) and other sensory tools after about 3 years. Taught professionally for groups after 4 years.

value.text: This isn’t based on a particular discourse rn, but like. I know the things I’ve done while being *extremely careful* that have been used against me due to antiblackness bc a white person felt like it, I can’t imagine doing some of the unhinged White People Shit y’all do because I’d be obliterated.

record.text: Because the risk isn’t just in the action of performing the kink, for Black folks, it’s also in what social repercussions we might be opening ourselves up to surrounding the kink. What racial stereotypes exist that may affect how we do the kink, or may stop us entirely.

Let’s talk Kink While Black.

I joined my local kink community at 18. Trained under two different Doms/Dommes in my home state, started teaching basic sensory play, especially knife play (not edgeplay) and other sensory tools after about 3 years. Taught professionally for groups after 4 years.

value.text: This isn’t based on a particular discourse rn, but like. I know the things I’ve done while being *extremely careful* that have been used against me due to antiblackness bc a white person felt like it, I can’t imagine doing some of the unhinged White People Shit y’all do because I’d be obliterated.

record.text: Because of the potential for situations like these, because of the potential for racialization that Black folks experience, we have to have a COMPLETELY different risk calculus for what kinks are “safe” for us to participate in than white folks do. Because even if we do it right, we could be targets

value.text: Nice to have the data to back up what I was experiencing. A lot of folks are just not using alt text. We should be encouraging folks to use alt text to make their images more accessible. Also reminding folks that they can flip the alt text reminder on in their settings if that is helpful.

Some new Bluesky stats for y'all.

We've seen ~400,000 posts per day for the past 9 days

Alt text usage has been holding steady at around ~26%
Around 15% of posts include images.

Daily active Posters floats around 70k
Daily active Likers floating around 90k

images.alt:
A graph of Daily Posts showing a recent plateau of around 400k posts per day. Before the plateau you can see a dip to around 300k posts per day and a surge at the start of the 30 day range of around 450k posts per day.

The graph also shows a line for % of posts with images and % of images with alt text. Alt text percentage fluctuates between 24% and 30% most recently plateauing around 26%.
A graph of active posters per day which fluctuates from ~80k to ~40k before surging up to >60k for the past 9 or so days.
A graph of likers per day showing ~85-90k average over the past 9 days, there is no data before then because I didn't start tracking the stat until recently.

value.text: Snake oil is a failure of government and our medical industry, not of individuals just trying to survive and be healthy. The “wellness” industry then preys on people’s lack of information. I don’t blame individuals, I blame institutions.

value.text: Thread of my favorite Baldwin quotes. Number 1 is obvious:

images.alt: To be a Negro in this country and to be relatively conscious is to be in a state of rage almost, almost all of the time — and in one's work. And part of the rage is this: It isn't only what is happening to you. But it's what's happening all around you and all of the time in the face of the most extraordinary and criminal indifference, indifference of most white people in this country, and their ignorance. Now, since this is so, it's a great temptation to simplify the issues under the illusion that if you simplify them enough, people will recognize them. I think this illusion is very dangerous because, in fact, it isn't the way it works. A complex thing can't be made simple. You simply have to try to deal with it in all its complexity and hope to get that complexity across.

To be a Negro in this country and to be relatively conscious is to be in a state of rage almost, almost all of the time — and in one's work. And part of the rage is this: It isn't only what is happening to you. But it's what's happening all around you and all of the time in the face of the most extraordinary and criminal indifference, indifference of most white people in this country, and their ignorance. Now, since this is so, it's a great temptation to simplify the issues under the illusion that if you simplify them enough, people will recognize them. I think this illusion is very dangerous because, in fact, it isn't the way it works. A complex thing can't be made simple. You simply have to try to deal with it in all its complexity and hope to get that complexity across.

Historically, any level of discomfort or “danger” has been used as an excuse to subject a Black person to varying levels of punishment for “not knowing their place” or for being a “threat”.

This has not been adequately unlearned and is still generally practiced by white folks in today’s society.

value.text: Nice to have the data to back up what I was experiencing. A lot of folks are just not using alt text. We should be encouraging folks to use alt text to make their images more accessible. Also reminding folks that they can flip the alt text reminder on in their settings if that is helpful.

Some new Bluesky stats for y'all.

We've seen ~400,000 posts per day for the past 9 days

Alt text usage has been holding steady at around ~26%
Around 15% of posts include images.

Daily active Posters floats around 70k
Daily active Likers floating around 90k

images.alt:
A graph of Daily Posts showing a recent plateau of around 400k posts per day. Before the plateau you can see a dip to around 300k posts per day and a surge at the start of the 30 day range of around 450k posts per day.

The graph also shows a line for % of posts with images and % of images with alt text. Alt text percentage fluctuates between 24% and 30% most recently plateauing around 26%.
A graph of active posters per day which fluctuates from ~80k to ~40k before surging up to >60k for the past 9 or so days.
A graph of likers per day showing ~85-90k average over the past 9 days, there is no data before then because I didn't start tracking the stat until recently.

Thread of my favorite Baldwin quotes. Number 1 is obvious:

images.alt: To be a Negro in this country and to be relatively conscious is to be in a state of rage almost, almost all of the time — and in one's work. And part of the rage is this: It isn't only what is happening to you. But it's what's happening all around you and all of the time in the face of the most extraordinary and criminal indifference, indifference of most white people in this country, and their ignorance. Now, since this is so, it's a great temptation to simplify the issues under the illusion that if you simplify them enough, people will recognize them. I think this illusion is very dangerous because, in fact, it isn't the way it works. A complex thing can't be made simple. You simply have to try to deal with it in all its complexity and hope to get that complexity across.

Now, since this is so, it's a great temptation to simplify the issues under the illusion that if you simplify them enough, people will recognize them. I think this illusion is very dangerous because, in fact, it isn't the way it works. A complex thing can't be made simple. You simply have to try to deal with it in all its complexity and hope to get that complexity across.

Historically, any level of discomfort or “danger” has been used as an excuse to subject a Black person to varying levels of punishment for “not knowing their place” or for being a “threat”.

This has not been adequately unlearned and is still generally practiced by white folks in today’s society.

To be a Negro in this country and to be relatively conscious is to be in a state of rage almost, almost all of the time — and in one's work. And part of the rage is this: It isn't only what is happening to you. But it's what's happening all around you and all of the time in the face of the most extraordinary and criminal indifference, indifference of most white people in this country, and their ignorance. Now, since this is so, it's a great temptation to simplify the issues under the illusion that if you simplify them enough, people will recognize them. I think this illusion is very dangerous because, in fact, it isn't the way it works. A complex thing can't be made simple. You simply have to try to deal with it in all its complexity and hope to get that complexity across.

value.text: Again, an example: disabled people demanded remote options for work and education for years and were told that these options were too difficult, too expensive, too time consuming. When COVID hit, suddenly every institution had the resources to do what disabled people asked for for years.

value.text: Snake oil is a failure of government and our medical industry, not of individuals just trying to survive and be healthy. The “wellness” industry then preys on people’s lack of information. I don’t blame individuals, I blame institutions.
